data.title: A Unique Name Doesn’t Make You Unique
data.meta_description: We all want to be memorable. Many celebrities in music, social media, and acting choose stage names that they feel will be memorable. That’s a fool’s game. Consider Arnold Schwarzenegger. He was told…
data.text:
August Adventures, Day 15

We all want to be memorable. Many celebrities in music, social media, and acting choose stage names that they feel will be memorable. That’s a fool’s game.

Consider Arnold Schwarzenegger. He was told by agents to change his name to make it easier to remember. (I had to look up the spelling just now.) He didn’t change it, and it didn’t matter, because he was memorable.

Don’t hide behind your name or think changing your name will change who you are. Change who you are, and people will remember your name.

Your nickname reinforces perceptions of you

When I was in single digits, my dad’s nickname for me was “Chubbles”. Even then, I knew nicknames reinforced perception — mine and others’. If I didn’t want to become morbidly obese, I needed a new nickname.

I ended up getting the nickname “Yennifer”, later shortened to “Yen-Yen”, because of a personalized hat. It read “Jennifer”, but the embroidery added a downstroke in front of the J that made it look like a Y. It was better than “Chubbles”.

In college, I got the nickname “Yeep”, for the noise I make when laughing. I embraced that…
